She always had an interesting perspective on why the world must be flat. I'd rather be a bird than a fish. I know many children ask for a pony, but I wanted a bicycle with rockets strapped to it. Swim at your own risk was taken as a challenge for the group of Kansas City college students. Abstraction is often one floor above you. Mom didn’t understand why no one else wanted a hot tub full of jello. It was a really good Monday for being a Saturday. It isn't difficult to do a handstand if you just stand on your hands. Acres of almond trees lined the interstate highway which complimented the crazy driving nuts. His mind was blown that there was nothing in space except space itself. She was disgusted he couldn’t tell the difference between lemonade and limeade. I used to live in my neighbor's fishpond, but the aesthetic wasn't to my taste. Please put on these earmuffs because I can't you hear. While all her friends were positive that Mary had a sixth sense, she knew she actually had a seventh sense. Best friends are like old tomatoes and shoelaces. She insisted that cleaning out your closet was the key to good driving. It's never comforting to know that your fate depends on something as unpredictable as the popping of corn. She wasn't sure whether to be impressed or concerned that he folded underwear in neat little packages. The Tsunami wave crashed against the raised houses and broke the pilings as if they were toothpicks. It was the first time he had ever seen someone cook dinner on an elephant.

I know this is old but since it wasn't properly explained I might as well. Temperature cannot be Vector. Harsni explained pretty well that the increase or decrease in temperature is a change in its intensity/magnitude and not in its direction. To give examples from the video, it works sort of in the same way as mass. When mass changes from, let's say, 40kg to 50kg it increases but that increase has nothing to do with its direction. It doesn't just move up or down, its value is the only number that changes (it doesn't move "up" so to speak). Now, if we compare the change in mass to displacement for example, displacement describes the change of position of an object, so you would need to give its distance from the starting point as well as the direction the object moves, making it Vector. Just as you can't describe an increase of mass with direction, you can't describe an increase of temperature with direction. I hope this helped, feel free to ask for any clarification.

See I look at the difference this way: All scalar quantities need only one poin to exist. That point is valued according to zero. Vectors must have two points and they don't have to respect zero.   For example: acceleration needs an initial point and a point to which you want to compare. How much did the the vehicle accelerate from 30mph to 40mph. Vectors use scalars to work.  On the other hand: speed needs one point and compares relative to zero. The man walked 10mph. 10mph is 10mph from zero. You could say the man ran 5mph faster than he walks, but you are still starting from as your initial speed you are adding to is referenced from zero.

Since this is a year old question I'm sure you probably know the answer by now but for anyone with a similar question: No, you cannot add vectors of different physical quantities. They have to be of the same physical quantity or else you end up mixing different values which would result in wrong answers.   For example let's say we have a box on a table. We push the box to the right with a force we'll call F1 and due to friction from the table, there's an opposite smaller force pushing the box to the left, we'll call it F2. Now since these two forces are opposing we would have to subtract the two forces to find the total force applied on the box in which case Ftotal=F1-F2 ( Because F1>F2 the total force will be facing right). Now if we put velocity into the mix we'd have only one vector and it would be pointing to the right (since that's where the box is moving). The velocity cannot be added to the Ftotal since velocity has nothing to do with the force placed on the box but instead its displacement in a certain timeframe. Since these quantities have nothing to do with each other, you would only serve to adding more quantity to the total force which would give you a wrong answer.   I am open to any more questions concerning this topic.
